questions.question:
Question 1: The WHO has formulated a Global Action Plan for the prevention and control of 
non-communicable diseases. Which of the following is not a voluntary global target under 
this initiative?

options.a: 10% relative reduction in harmful use of alcohol
options.b: 30% relative reduction in mean population intake of sodium
options.c: 10% relative reduction in prevalence of insufficient physical activity
options.d: 10% relative reduction in use of trans-fat for cooking

questions.explanation:
A 10 percent relative reduction in the use of trans-fat for cooking is not a voluntary global target 
under the WHO Global Action Plan for prevention and control of non-communicable diseases. There are 9 targets under this plan which are to be achieved by 2025. These are shown in the 
image below.

questions.question: Question 2: Project MONICA is related to:
questions.explanation:
Project MONICA is related to cardiovascular diseases. It stands for multinational monitoring of trends and determinants in cardiovascular diseases. It 
was done to study the reasons for the changes in the trends of cardiovascular diseases in different 
countries.

questions.question:
Question 3: Which of the following statements is false regarding the relationship between smoking and 
coronary heart disease (CHD)?

options.a: Smoking can cause sudden death from CHD.
options.b: Filters in cigarettes are protective against the development of CHD.
options.c: Risk of developing CHD 10-20 years after the cessation of smoking is equal in smokers and non
options.d: Degree of risk of developing CHD is directly related to the number of cigarettes smoked per

questions.explanation:
Filters are probably not protective against the development of coronary heart disease in smokers. Smoking is a modifiable risk factor for coronary heart disease (CHD). The degree of risk is directly 
related to the number of cigarettes smoked per day. Several mechanisms have been suggested for 
this: • Carbon monoxide induced atherogenesis • Nicotine stimulation of adrenergic drive • Lipid metabolism with fall in levels of HDL Cigarettes also increase the risk of sudden death in patients with CHD who are below 50 years of 
age. The risk of death from CHD decreases with the cessation of smoking. The risk declines quite 328 
Sold by @itachibot substantially within one year of stopping smoking and more gradually thereafter until, after 10- 
20 years, it is the same as that of non-smokers. Risk factors for coronary heart disease are: • Modifiable: • Cigarette smoking • High blood pressure • Elevated serum cholesterol • Diabetes • Obesity • Sedentary habits • Stress • Non-modifiable: • Age • Sex • Family history • Genetic factors • Personality

questions.question:
Question 4: 321 
Sold by @itachibot A chronic smoker was found to have a deranged lipid profile during his annual health 
checkup. Which of the following variables tested is most directly associated with the risk of 
developing coronary heart disease?
questions.explanation:
The plasma LDL level is most directly associated with the risk of developing coronary heart 
disease (CHD). HDL is protective against the development of CHD. Its levels should ideally be more than 40 
mg/dl. Recent evidence shows that levels of Apolipoprotein-A-1 and Apolipoprotein-B are better 
predictors of CHD than HDL or LDL. VLDL is more strongly associated with the risk of developing peripheral vascular disease.

questions.question:
Question 5: A 45-year-old diabetic male is concerned about his risk of developing coronary heart disease. 
What cholesterol/HDL ratio would you aim to achieve in this patient?
questions.explanation:
A cholesterol/HDL ratio <3.5 is recommended for the prevention of coronary heart disease 
(CHD).

questions.question:
Question 6: While conducting a screening camp for coronary heart disease, you encounter the following 
people. Who among them is at the highest risk for developing this disease?

options.a: A person who is competitive and ambitious
options.b: A person who is calm and relaxed
options.c: A person who tends to suppress their emotions
options.d: An introverted person with negative affectivity

questions.explanation:
329 
Sold by @itachibot A person who is competitive and ambitious is said to have a type A personality. Such people are 
more prone to develop coronary heart disease (CHD). Personality type is a non-modifiable risk 
factor for CHD. Risk factors for coronary heart disease are: • Modifiable: • Cigarette smoking • High blood pressure • Elevated serum cholesterol • Diabetes • Obesity • Sedentary habits • Stress • Non-modifiable: • Age • Sex • Family history • Genetic factors • Personality Option B: A calm and relaxed person is said to have a type B personality. Option C: A person who tends to suppress their emotions, especially negative emotions, is said to 
have a type C personality. Option D: A person with negative affectivity and social inhibition is said to have a type D 
personality.

questions.question:
Question 7: A 45-year-old obese woman enquires about ways she can reduce her risk of coronary artery 
disease. Which of the following dietary modifications would you suggest?

options.a: Reduction of salt intake to less than 10g per day
options.b: Consumption of saturated fats limited to less than 10% of the total energy intake
options.c: Reduction of total fat intake to less than 5% of total energy intake
options.d: Dietary cholesterol increased to above 100 mg/1000 kcal energy intake

questions.explanation:
Limiting the consumption of saturated fats to less than 10% of total energy intake is 
recommended for the prevention of coronary artery disease. The WHO'S Expert Committee suggested certain dietary modifications for the prevention of 
coronary artery disease. These include: • Reduction of the total fat intake to 20–30% of total energy intake • Consumption of saturated fats must be limited to less than 10% of total energy intake • A reduction of dietary cholesterol to below 100mg per 1000 kcal per day • Increase in the complex carbohydrate consumption (i.e vegetables, fruits, whole grains and 
legumes) • Avoidance of alcohol consumption and reduction of salt intake to 5g daily or less 330 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.explanation:

questions.question:
Question 9: A 50-year-old man, under treatment for hypertension for the past two months, is found to 
have a blood pressure of 144/96 mmHg. How will you grade it according to the European 
society of cardiology guidelines-2018?
questions.explanation:
According to the European society of cardiology guidelines-2018, a patient having a systolic 
BP140 and a diastolic BP90 mmHg is classified as having grade 1 hypertension.

questions.question:
Question 10: A doctor records the BP of a patient as 142/90mmHg. One hour later, another doctor records 
the BP of the same patient as 160/98 mmHg. Both the readings are measured with the same 
apparatus under the same emotional and physical state of the patient. What type of error is 
seen here?
questions.explanation:
Such errors can arise due to differences in hearing acuity and interpretation of Korotkoff sounds. The types of errors that can occur during the measurement of blood pressure include: • Observer errors - due to difference in hearing acuity and interpretation of Korotkoff sounds • Instrumental errors - due to a leaking valve or cuffs that do not encircle the arm completely • Subject errors - due to anxiety, fear, etc. of the patient 331 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 11: What does number 2 in the given diagram related to hypertension denote? 323 
Sold by @itachibot

options.c: Diagnosed hypertensive subjects not on treatment

questions.explanation:
The above diagram depicts the "rule of halves", which shows the distribution of hypertension in 
the community. The number 2 in this diagram denotes normotensive subjects. The rule of halves is a way of depicting the iceberg phenomenon seen in hypertension. It depicts 
that only about half of the hypertensive subjects in the general population of most developed 
countries are aware of the condition and only half of those aware are being treated and only half 
of those being treated are considered to be adequately treated. The circles marked by numbers in the given diagram correspond to the following parts of the 
population: • Whole community • Normotensive subjects • Hypertensive subjects • Undiagnosed hypertension • Diagnosed hypertension • Diagnosed but untreated • Diagnosed and treated • Inadequately treated • Adequately treated

questions.question: Question 12: Which of the following statements is true regarding tracking of blood pressure?

options.a: BP increases with age in all individuals
options.b: BP falls steadily in the elderly
options.c: Hypertensive children become hypotensive as they grow
options.d: BP of hypotensive children tends to remain low in adult life

questions.explanation:
If the blood pressure of individuals is followed up over years from early childhood to adult life, 
low blood pressures tend to remain low and high blood pressures become higher as the 
individuals grow older. This phenomenon of persistence of the rank order of blood pressure is 
described as tracking. This is helpful in identifying children and adolescents who are at risk of developing hypertension 
in the future. Although blood pressure is known to increase with age in both sexes, some communities have 
been identified whose mean blood pressure does not rise with age. This is because their salt intake 
and calorie consumption are at a subsistence level.

questions.question:
Question 13: While formulating a diet plan for a hypertensive patient, you advise salt restriction. How 
much reduction in systolic blood pressure is expected by this intervention?
questions.explanation:
Salt restriction or decreasing dietary sodium intake decreases the systolic blood pressure by 2-8 
mmHg approximately. Lifestyle modifications to manage hypertension: Note: DASH stands for dietary approaches to stop hypertension. 332

questions.question:
Question 14: Which of the following interventions will cause the maximum decrease in systolic blood 
pressure in a hypertensive patient?

options.b: Taking a brisk walk for at least 30 minutes a day
options.d: Restricting sodium intake to less than 6g per day

questions.explanation:
Among the above options, adopting the dietary approaches to stop hypertension (DASH) eating 
plan causes maximum decrease in systolic BP. It decreases the systolic BP by 8-14 mm Hg. Lifestyle modifications to manage hypertension: Recommendation

questions.question:
Question 15: Which of the following is a minor criterion for the diagnosis of rheumatic fever in a low risk 
population?
questions.explanation: Polyarthralgia is a minor criterion for the diagnosis of rheumatic fever in a low risk population.

questions.question:
Question 16: A child having strep throat is being prescribed benzathine penicillin G. Which level of 
prevention of rheumatic fever does this intervention fall under?
questions.explanation:
The given scenario is an example of primary mode of prevention of rheumatic fever. This is 
because the patient only has strep throat and rheumatic fever has not developed yet. In case benzathine penicillin G is given to a patient with rheumatic fever to prevent further 
complications, then it becomes secondary level of prevention.

questions.question:
Question 17: A 16-year-old boy with rheumatic fever developed carditis which subsequently healed in a 
couple of weeks. How long will you administer benzathine penicillin G for secondary 
prophylaxis to him?
questions.explanation:
In the given scenario, benzathine penicillin G for secondary prophylaxis should be given for 10 
years from the last attack i.e, till 26 years of age. The given case is of rheumatic fever with carditis 
but with no residual valvular disease, for which secondary prophylaxis is given for 10 years from 
the last attack or till 21 years of age, whichever is longer. Recommendations for the duration of secondary prophylaxis with penicillin: Category of the patient

questions.question: Question 18: Which of the following is not a protective factor for diabetes mellitus?
questions.explanation:
A higher intake of saturated fats is associated with an increased risk of diabetes mellitus. Dietary factors that are protective for diabetes mellitus are: • Higher intake of unsaturated fatty acids • A minimum daily intake of 20g of dietary fibre 334 
Sold by @itachibot • Exclusive breastfeeding

questions.question:
Question 19: A patient's fasting plasma glucose is 122 mg/dl and postprandial plasma glucose is 138 mg/dl. 
According to the WHO diagnostic criteria for diabetes, which category does this patient fall 
under?
questions.explanation:
Fasting blood glucose of 122 mg/dl with a postprandial value of 138 mg/dl indicates the patient 
falls under the criteria for impaired fasting glucose. The WHO diagnostic criteria for diabetes and intermediate hyperglycemia is as follows: Diagnosis Fasting plasma gluco

questions.question:
Question 20: Which of the following statements are incorrect regarding the benefits of various 
interventions in diabetes?
questions.explanation:
The use of ACE inhibitors in diabetics reduces the risk of nephropathy by 42% and cardiovascular 
risk by 22%. Annual eye examination in diabetics reduces the incidence of serious visual loss by 
60-™0%. Interventions in diabetes: • Glycaemic control in diabetics with HbA1C > 9% reduces microvascular disease risk by 30% 
per 1% drop in HbA1c. • Blood pressure control in patients with BP > 130/80 mmHg reduces microvascular and 
macrovascular disease risk by 35% per 10 mmHg drop in blood pressure. • Lifestyle modification reduces the incidence of diabetes by 35-58%. • Metformin administered as a preventive therapy reduces the incidence of diabetes by 25-31%. • Proper foot care reduces the risk of serious foot disease by 50-60%.

questions.question:
Question 21: The community health officer of an area is instructed to assess the population for the risk 
factors of Non-alcoholic Fatty Liver Disease under NP-NCD. Which of the following will not 326 
Sold by @itachibot be a risk factor?

options.c: Ca oral cavity and Ca breast

questions.explanation:
Low blood pressure is not a risk factor for NAFLD according to the NP-NCD. The National Programme for Prevention & Control of Non-Communicable Diseases 
(NP-NCD), which was earlier NPCDCS, has integrated guidelines for the management of 
Non-alcoholic Fatty Liver disease (NAFLD) into its framework. Through a community-based 
assessment checklist, the community health officer along with ASHA workers will assess for the 
presence of the following risk factors: 335 
Sold by @itachibot • Abdominal obesity (waist circumference of >90cm in men and >80cm in women) • Personal or family history of diabetes, hypertension, cancers, heart diseases, liver diseases or 
gallstones • Obesity (BMI >23 kg/m2) • Presence of pedal edema Level of healthcare
